official-title.#text: To amend the Diplomatic Security Act to require certain notifications to Congress of Accountability Review Boards of the Department of State, avoid conflicts of interest of the members of such Boards, require actions with respect to reports from such Boards, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Accountability Review Board Reform Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The United States has a crucial stake in supporting the presence abroad of United States Government personnel representing United States interests.
United States Government personnel and missions abroad are confronted by serious security risks, including the threat of terrorism, which will continue for the foreseeable future.
The Accountability Review Board process was established in 1986 by Congress to conduct a thorough assessment of security-related incidents at or related to a United States Government mission abroad.
Each assessment by a Board is expected to promote strengthened security measures, and to provide for the accountability of United States Government personnel with security-related responsibilities.
The terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, on September 11, 2012, that took the lives of four United States Government personnel has brought unprecedented attention to the work of such Boards.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that the effectiveness of Accountability Review Boards would be improved by reconstituting such Boards to increase their independence from the

text.#text: It is the sense of

quote.#text: A Board shall consist of five members, two appointed by the

text.#text: by striking the first sentence and inserting the following new sentence:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , for each day (including travel time) during which such members are engaged in the actual performance of duties vested in such Board. Members of the Board who are Federal officers or employees shall receive no additional pay by reason of such membership. Only in exceptional circumstances may a member of a Board be a current Federal officer or employee.

quote.#text: Members of a Board who are not Federal officers or employees shall each be paid at a rate not to exceed the maximum rate of basic pay payable for level IV of the Executive Schedule under

text.#text: A Board may hire staff to assist the Board, and may have any Federal Government employee assigned or detailed to such Board, with or without reimbursement, to assist such Board. Any such assignee or detailee shall retain without interruption the rights, status, and privileges of his or her regular employment.

may not appoint any individual as a member of a Board if the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Director of National Intelligence

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the CIGIE Chairperson, or the
, as the case may be, determines that such individual has a conflict of interest concerning a person whose performance such Board reasonably could be expected to review.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Director of National Intelligence

text.#text: The

An individual shall decline appointment to membership on a Board if such individual has actual knowledge of a conflict of interest concerning a person whose performance such Board could reasonably be expected to review.

A member of a Board shall recuse him or herself from any Board activity, interview, deposition, or recommendation concerning a person with whom such member has a conflict of interest. Such member shall promptly notify the other members of such Board of any such recusal, but need not state the basis therefor.

quote.#tail: means one of the following relationships, whether current or former, that would cause a reasonable person with knowledge of the relevant facts to question the impartiality of the parties to such relationship toward each other:

text.#text: In this section, the term
A business, contractual, or other financial relationship that involves other than a routine consumer transaction.
A familial, member of household, or other close personal relationship, including a social relationship of a romantic or intimate nature.
A direct managerial or supervisory workplace relationship.

text.#text: The Board may accept any evidence determined by a member of the Board to be relevant and material to an investigation or inquiry of the Board. The Federal Rules of Evidence are not applicable to the Board.

text.#text: The
The amendments made by this Act shall apply with respect to any case of an Accountability Review Board that is convened under
